The principai ard most interesting transaction in
Congress- since our las, report was the introduction
IN both H'uses, on Monday, oi bill 10 regulate The
com cial ittt ttcoUrse between the United States
and Gteat Britain. " The object of the bilp' says
the National lntelgencee, is TO pre- vent the admis-
sion any vessels into the ports OF The United States
alter the SOth day ni September from the Col
onies ard possessions of Great Britain, including
them ell by oame except Upper Canada with a
provision lor the suspension OF the act in either Of
two cases. viz First if the President shall re ceiye
satisfactory evidence that the ports in the British
Noionies and POSSESSIONS are open to the admission
OF vessels Of the United States, paving no higher
or other duties than those levied on British yes
sells, and that our vessels are permitted to export
theretrom the same pr oduce and on the same terms,
as British vessels then this act may be suspended
by proclamation OF the President. Secondly: the
bli proposes the provision which Mr.. Gallatin
was authorised 10 propose to The British Govern
ment VIZ that if vessels Of the United States are
admitted into the British Colonies or possessions


ps'HS M HiRner duties tnan the vessels oil Great
Britain, and permitted to export thence, to any
country except Great Britain, any articles which
British vessels may export, then The President may
declare, by proclamation, that British vessels arr-
wing in the United States from the Colonies of Great
Bi ain, shall MOI be subjected to any higher duties
than vessels Of The Unied States, SC.


From and after the date OF such proclamation, in
either case, The acts of Congress Of 1918, 1920,
and 1873, being all the acts restricting this trade,
ale declared to be repealed the effect Of which
repeal will be, TO leave tish vessels liberty to
clear from the United States TO any country what
ever as our vessels may clear thence.


The general language of this act is to ssy, to the
nish Government,ityo you will open the direct trade
between The United States and the Colonies, we will
do the same: if you insist on the circui,ous trade.
we shall follow your lead. The bill seems to be fra
med in spirit Of smy, by which also there port of
The Committee Of Commerce in each House ap
pears to be characteized. At this we are the more
gra,hed, as We are decidedly opposed to any
thing like quarrel between the two nations upon
any question such as the one involved in this con
rovcrsy, which each na,i has ndis putable right
10 act upon municipality, without offence TO the 9th
er. We have no doubt that, in the end, Great Brit
ain will see her intcres, in reiracing her steps, see
10y that the United States is entirely disposed to
ict towards her on principles Of reoiproci,y'


The bill was read twice in The House and made
the order o the day for Tuesdsy--but as the Intel
genccr containing the proceedings OF that day has
net come TO hand, we are with out Information as 10
wha was done in the case.

II FoRT DKLAwARE.--This work will be finished
in the course Of the year. Ne injuries produce ed
ny the sinking OF the undeons will then have
been thoroughly repaired The subsistence of the

| The Engineer of Fort Delaware, in pursuance
of instructions has furnished plan for the Piers
required to be built in the river Delaware, al New
Castle. The sum estimated TO be necessary for
ne iuhment, is greater than the appr ropriated
tor that purpose. i he place is designed as well 10
| afford shelter to vessels from floating ice and
storms, as to produce greater depth around the
old Piers by diverting from its regular course the
current OF the river, and causing it act against
the alluviai deposile, by the accumulation of which
around the old Piers, the depth at them has been
progressively diminished. partial complexion of
The plan would fulfil the first object, should its ex.
tent be adequate TO the accommodation Of the num-
Der OF vessels which msy require the shelter il
would be designed to afford, but its entire compile
tion is supposed to be necessary to effect the Sc.
cond object stated. Ii is possible, however, thyt
both may be fulfilled BY partial completion Of The
plan to the extent the appropriation would author
ice. The mode proposed for The construction Of
the Piers, has. the efore been adapted to this pos
sble event. The whole length of each Pier $50
feet, instead Of being constructed continuously, is
intended 10 be composed OF series OF blocks each 25
ieet in lene h, to be laid in accession, and con.
taL ha;o lo;J II, q, a:
bic Of curtailment or enlargement without impair
ing its efficacy


II is suggested that the repaifSf the old Piers be
postponed until il shall be ascertained whether the
new Piers will produce The effect anticipated, Of
deepening the water around them.

Charleston. S. e. Jan. 10.
| EXTRAORDINARY EFFORT-We yester.
day notIhed our readers that in the course OF the
present week, wager would be decided, that a en-
tieman OF this city, would drive his horse around
the race course fifty times (equal to SO miles) il
FIVE hours The weather proving favourable, and
the course being in good order, the attempt wa.
made yesterday with the most complete SUCCESS
Mr. John Randolph, the gentleman alluded to. com
menced it about Il O'Clock. A. NJ. and sl,hougt
necessarily obliged TO stop occasionally, say four OF
hvc times tor about minute each time reached
The starting post after completing the 6y miles, in
4 hours 81 minutes and 46 seconds--being min
ues IA seconds within the time appointed.


This match against time, unparalleled certainly 10
this country, and We believe elsewhere, was accom-.
pshed moreover without any apparent injury to the
horse. Indeed. such was the power he still exhib
tied, that seious accident occurred from ii, which
had nearly proved fatal 10 Mr.. Randolph. Upon
his coming in, the loud and repeated cheering OF
the spectators, startled the horke-when he imme.
dlatey ran oH--the bit breaking, he became unman- :
ageable and after proceeding nearly to the lines.
threw Mr. Raodolph out and severely bruised him.
He then escaped from the Sulkey, and was retaken
with much difficulty We are very happy howev
ever, 10 learn that Mir. Randolph is not seriously in
jured-and suffers more from his fatigue and ex-
haustion, than from his contusons Gaz.


The North american Reuiew for January con
taIns several articles Of interest," some OF which we
shall notice more particularly hereafter. The scho-
ars and he scientific men Of the country should de
sire to see this journal, which finds its way farther
III Europe than any similar American work, made
as interesting and mpreheusive as possible, and
the repository of information aud thought on the
many important subjects 10 which the progress o
The country is continually giving rise. The talents
and requirements, and indeiatatigableness of the
presen, editor, are we'll adapted to sustain the high
and increasing reputation oi the work.

The principai ard most interesting transaction in
Congress- since our las, report was the introduction
IN both H'uses, on Monday, oi bill 10 regulate The
com cial ittt ttcoUrse between the United States
and Gteat Britain. " The object of the bilp' says
the National lntelgencee, is TO pre- vent the admis-
sion any vessels into the ports OF The United States
alter the SOth day ni September from the Col
onies ard possessions of Great Britain, including
them ell by oame except Upper Canada with a
provision lor the suspension OF the act in either Of
two cases. viz First if the President shall re ceiye
satisfactory evidence that the ports in the British
Noionies and POSSESSIONS are open to the admission
OF vessels Of the United States, paving no higher
or other duties than those levied on British yes
sells, and that our vessels are permitted to export
theretrom the same pr oduce and on the same terms,
as British vessels then this act may be suspended
by proclamation OF the President. Secondly: the
bli proposes the provision which Mr.. Gallatin
was authorised 10 propose to The British Govern
ment VIZ that if vessels Of the United States are
admitted into the British Colonies or possessions


ps'HS M HiRner duties tnan the vessels oil Great
Britain, and permitted to export thence, to any
country except Great Britain, any articles which
British vessels may export, then The President may
declare, by proclamation, that British vessels arr-
wing in the United States from the Colonies of Great
Bi ain, shall MOI be subjected to any higher duties
than vessels Of The Unied States, SC.


From and after the date OF such proclamation, in
either case, The acts of Congress Of 1918, 1920,
and 1873, being all the acts restricting this trade,
ale declared to be repealed the effect Of which
repeal will be, TO leave tish vessels liberty to
clear from the United States TO any country what
ever as our vessels may clear thence.


The general language of this act is to ssy, to the
nish Government,ityo you will open the direct trade
between The United States and the Colonies, we will
do the same: if you insist on the circui,ous trade.
we shall follow your lead. The bill seems to be fra
med in spirit Of smy, by which also there port of
The Committee Of Commerce in each House ap
pears to be characteized. At this we are the more
gra,hed, as We are decidedly opposed to any
thing like quarrel between the two nations upon
any question such as the one involved in this con
rovcrsy, which each na,i has ndis putable right
10 act upon municipality, without offence TO the 9th
er. We have no doubt that, in the end, Great Brit
ain will see her intcres, in reiracing her steps, see
10y that the United States is entirely disposed to
ict towards her on principles Of reoiproci,y'


The bill was read twice in The House and made
the order o the day for Tuesdsy--but as the Intel
genccr containing the proceedings OF that day has
net come TO hand, we are with out Information as 10
wha was done in the case.


uoffto 90

regard to burias by which poor and the rich b.twee
whom the most nydous distinctions had been made, are
to have the same rights throughout the process The
Brothers OF the Order of Charity to carry all ake to
the grave, and the Church pay the fees when the
family Of the detunct unable to discharge them.

4 for the year 1925.


II FoRT DKLAwARE.--This work will be finished
in the course Of the year. Ne injuries produce ed
ny the sinking OF the undeons will then have
been thoroughly repaired The subsistence of the
foundations, during thi, yea', has been less than
heretofore, and its tendency 10 increase old, and
produce new injuries, has been Of comparatively
limited extent. 1t is proposed to load the founda-
lions, practicable, with the armament in
tended Tor the Tort and, by that MEANS should they
be still liable to further subsistence to accelerate it,
hat Its maximum may be a,critainrd. Ii is be-
lieved II the work does not possess it, that it
will be practicable to give to 1t, ultimately the
strength and stability requisite to the tulfiment Of
The objects for which it is designed.
| The Engineer of Fort Delaware, in pursuance
of instructions has furnished plan for the Piers
required to be built in the river Delaware, al New
Castle. The sum estimated TO be necessary for
ne iuhment, is greater than the appr ropriated
tor that purpose. i he place is designed as well 10
| afford shelter to vessels from floating ice and
storms, as to produce greater depth around the
old Piers by diverting from its regular course the
current OF the river, and causing it act against
the alluviai deposile, by the accumulation of which
around the old Piers, the depth at them has been
progressively diminished. partial complexion of
The plan would fulfil the first object, should its ex.
tent be adequate TO the accommodation Of the num-
Der OF vessels which msy require the shelter il
would be designed to afford, but its entire compile
tion is supposed to be necessary to effect the Sc.
cond object stated. Ii is possible, however, thyt
both may be fulfilled BY partial completion Of The
plan to the extent the appropriation would author
ice. The mode proposed for The construction Of
the Piers, has. the efore been adapted to this pos
sble event. The whole length of each Pier $50
feet, instead Of being constructed continuously, is
intended 10 be composed OF series OF blocks each 25
ieet in lene h, to be laid in accession, and con.
taL ha;o lo;J II, q, a:
bic Of curtailment or enlargement without impair
ing its efficacy


II is suggested that the repaifSf the old Piers be
postponed until il shall be ascertained whether the
new Piers will produce The effect anticipated, Of
deepening the water around them.

full articles.headline: Charleston. S. G. Jan. 10.
full articles.article:
Charleston. S. e. Jan. 10.
| EXTRAORDINARY EFFORT-We yester.
day notIhed our readers that in the course OF the
present week, wager would be decided, that a en-
tieman OF this city, would drive his horse around
the race course fifty times (equal to SO miles) il
FIVE hours The weather proving favourable, and
the course being in good order, the attempt wa.
made yesterday with the most complete SUCCESS
Mr. John Randolph, the gentleman alluded to. com
menced it about Il O'Clock. A. NJ. and sl,hougt
necessarily obliged TO stop occasionally, say four OF
hvc times tor about minute each time reached
The starting post after completing the 6y miles, in
4 hours 81 minutes and 46 seconds--being min
ues IA seconds within the time appointed.


This match against time, unparalleled certainly 10
this country, and We believe elsewhere, was accom-.
pshed moreover without any apparent injury to the
horse. Indeed. such was the power he still exhib
tied, that seious accident occurred from ii, which
had nearly proved fatal 10 Mr.. Randolph. Upon
his coming in, the loud and repeated cheering OF
the spectators, startled the horke-when he imme.
dlatey ran oH--the bit breaking, he became unman- :
ageable and after proceeding nearly to the lines.
threw Mr. Raodolph out and severely bruised him.
He then escaped from the Sulkey, and was retaken
with much difficulty We are very happy howev
ever, 10 learn that Mir. Randolph is not seriously in
jured-and suffers more from his fatigue and ex-
haustion, than from his contusons Gaz.


The North american Reuiew for January con
taIns several articles Of interest," some OF which we
shall notice more particularly hereafter. The scho-
ars and he scientific men Of the country should de
sire to see this journal, which finds its way farther
III Europe than any similar American work, made
as interesting and mpreheusive as possible, and
the repository of information aud thought on the
many important subjects 10 which the progress o
The country is continually giving rise. The talents
and requirements, and indeiatatigableness of the
presen, editor, are we'll adapted to sustain the high
and increasing reputation oi the work.
